children.subject:
As Michael pointed out the while loop over \ell is not getting restarted, \ell simply increases.  That is why the for loop with the nested while loop is a total of O(n) time.

I'm not expecting solutions like this (with any sort of pre-processing) for the homework or exam problems; this is just included in the solutions as a side note.
I don't thing you're missing anything.

history.content:
Note that l=0 is outside of both loops, so the incremented value of l persists between iterations of the for loop. I think the first part of the conditional of the while statement (with the j typo) can be dropped.

The for loop with the while loop inside is filling out our last(·) array which should just take O(n) time as the persistent l iterator means that the while loop should only be taking constant time.

My question is regarding the total run time of Algorithm 5 FasterYuckDonalds (from DPV-DP-6.1-6.4.pdf) as written. Keep in mind that there is a typo in the solution, see (@85). I believe the calculation of last(i) takes O(n^2) run time giving the algorithm a total run time of O(n^2).

I believe this is so since the for loop goes from i=1 to i=n [giving the for loop O(n) run time] and the while loop goes from l=0 to l=i-1. Since the while loop goes to i-1 and i is at worst n this gives the while loop O(n) run time.

Or am I missing something and it is O(n) total run time?
history.subject: 6.3 YuckDonald's - Algorithm 5 FasterYuckDonalds Solution in DPV-DP-6.1-6.4.pdf
